Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Institutional Ethnography of the Social Dynamics of a Bureaucracy in Historical Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
All institutions display social and bureaucratic dynamics that affect how the institutions function. In the United States, health care provisioning institutions are particularly important because they comprise the majority of care facilities for the American public. The goal of the research funded by this award is to identify organizational factors that affect health care provisioning outcomes but are not necessarily directly related to technical expertise. The research will be undertaken by Adrienne Strong, a doctoral student at Washington University St. Louis, who works under the guidance of medical anthropologist, Dr. Carolyn Sargent. Strong has chosen to focus on the bureaucratic, institutional, and social dynamics that contribute to maternal deaths in biomedical care settings, because this is an area where the United States is known to lag behind other Western nations. She will conduct the research as an in-depth institutional ethnography of a hospital in the Rukwa region of Tanzania. Because the region has high rates of maternal mortality, the links between outcomes on the one hand and institutional structures and processes on the other will be easier to identify than they would in the United States where a single institution would provide too few events to study. In addition, understanding the social and bureaucratic dynamics of health care facilities in Africa is important for being able to stem the rising tide of globally significant infectious disease epidemics.

Strong will collect data on sequences of events at the hospital, and on historical, institutional, and political economic structures that shape maternal risk. She will employ a variety of qualitative research methods, including in-depth interviews with government officials, health administrators, nurses and doctors, traditional birth attendants, and pregnant women and their families. She also will observe at the hospital; hold group discussions with women and community leaders; and conduct a work empowerment survey of health care providers. She will concentrate on four topics: 1) How institutional factors and strategies of health care providers shape obstetric emergencies; 2) Sequences of events preceding a woman's arrival at the hospital during an obstetric emergency; 3) How life events, social relations, and other community factors influence maternal health; and 4) Connections between historical processes and the current functioning of the health care system. Similar methods can be used in the United States to identify new sites for intervention to interrupt the pathway to maternal death once the underlying processes are identified. Strong's data will allow her to analyze communication (among medical professionals, between staff and patients, between women and their families or communities); health care provider morale and motivation; and administrator strategies and goals. Understanding these factors will complement the extensive previous research on the clinical and community causes of maternal death. This will contribute to social scientific understanding of the workings of bureaucratic institutions in general as well as low-cost solutions for improving health care in particular. Public health policies everywhere encourage women to give birth in biomedical care facilities. Strong's research will generate novel insight into the sequences of events leading to deaths in these settings from the unique perspectives of the providers, administrators, patients, and their communities. Understanding the social and organizational workings of health care institutions will help to develop avenues for improving their quality and efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to generate a novel perspective of the on-going problem of maternal mortality. Even as fewer women die during pregnancy now than ever before, nearly 300,000 women, primarily in lower income countries, continue to die each year due to pregnancy related causes. Public health and advocacy campaigns have sought to encourage women to give birth in healthcare facilities but there has been little qualitative research that explores what happens when women enter these facilities or develop life-threatening obstetric complications within their walls. Through over 1600 hours of time spent on a regional referral hospital maternity ward, in-depth interviews with doctors, nurses, and healthcare administrators, three months of focus group discussions and interviews in surrounding communities with nearly 500 participants, as well as three months of primary document research in the Tanzania National Archives, we collected data to more fully understand what leads to a pregnant mother’s death in a healthcare facility. Contemporary and historical information helped the researchers to explain the ways in which the healthcare system in Tanzania is succeeding and where it continues to struggle when seeking to reduce maternal and neonatal deaths. Several present-day challenges have roots in the colonial and/or immediate post-Independence eras via physical infrastructure or education, economic, and social policies. Community members provided important background information about the challenges facing women in terms of gender relations, access to education, and general access to healthcare services, as well as community challenges such as lack of clean water and poor crop yields for people depending on farming for survival and profit.

Through observation and interviews, it became clear, over the course of the project, that healthcare providers work in institutions characterized by shortage and scarcity, as well as rigid bureaucratic protocols. Despite these constraints, maternity ward staff members worked to make the best of what supplies and facilities were available in order to try to save women’s lives during emergencies. In the absence of disciplinary or reward systems at the hospital, providers and hospital administrators struggled to address deaths, including those that sometimes resulted from what they themselves called neglect. Nurses and doctors who went above and beyond the call of duty rarely received any form of praise or recognition.

In addition to the practical applications of learning more about where communication and clinical care broke down, this research contributes to several new and growing areas of theoretical interest in the field of cultural anthropology. This is the first study of its kind to explicitly explore maternal death from the perspective of healthcare providers and administrators in a low resource setting. Therefore, the data collected provide us with a new understanding of the ways in which this group of people makes meaning and copes with death in difficult work environments. The project also contributes to our understanding of how biomedicine changes and is transformed by patients and practitioners throughout the world.
